webTitle: Bank of England: UK recovery has finally taken hold - as it happened

fields.standfirst:
• Mark Carney: The glass is half-full
• Summary of the BoE Quarterly Inflation Report
• UK unemployment rate drops to 7.6%
• EC starts probe into German trade surplus
fields.body:
5.13pm GMT

European markets have ended on the back foot, mainly due to continuing concerns that central banks - particularly the US Federal Reserve and the Bank of England - might soon turn off the money taps. Investors had expected the Fed to begin winding down its $85bn a month bond buying programme next year, but there are growing hints it might end sooner. Meanwhile the UK economy appears to be growing more strongly than expected, bringing forward the prospect of rising interest rates. Conversely, the European Central Bank could yet buy assets from banks and sanction negative deposit rates, according to board member Peter Praet. So here are the market movements:

• The FTSE 100 is down 96.79 points or 1.44% at 6630.00, its biggest one day fall since 15 August

• Germany's Dax has dropped 0.24% to 9054.83

• France's Cac closed 0.56% lower at 4239.94

• Italy's FTSE MIB fell 1.43% to 18,733.02

• Spain's Ibex ended down 0.33% at 9675.2

On Wall Street, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is currently 50 points or 0.32% lower.

On that note, it's time to close up for the evening. Thanks for all the comments, and we'll be back tomorrow for another busy day.

5.11pm GMT

Something to please Mark Carney (probably):

4.31pm GMT

Meanwhile, in Madrid......

Updated at 4.32pm GMT

4.15pm GMT

Over in Greece, the country is said to be on track to balance its budget this year. According to deputy finance minister Christos Staikouras, the recovery has been helped by a recovery in tax revenues. AP has the story:

Staikouras said the country was expected to post a budget surplus of about €345m before interest payments this year a key target set by bailout lenders.

The January-October balance stood at €1.1bn, Staikouras said, after traditionally weak tax revenues came in €250m above target, at €35.59bn for the 10-month period.

"It seems that the country will meet its national target. Of course, this is due to the enormous sacrifices made by Greeks, unprecedented in post-war Europe," Staikouras said.

Unemployment in Greece is nearing 28%, amid rapidly increasing poverty due to years of austerity measures imposed in exchange for the bailout program worth €240bn.

Greece is currently in talks with bailout inspectors to try and resolve a disagreement over 2014 budget cuts and how to ease government protection for distressed mortgages.

The left-wing opposition Syriza described the negotiations as a sham.

"These negotiations with the Europeans are a charade. The (government) is in fact reciting its loyalty to its lenders," a party statement said. "Its goal was and remains the resolute implementation of bailout commitments with no consideration for the social cost."

3.09pm GMT

Euro drops as ECB hints at possible negative rates or QE

The euro has come under pressure after an ECB board member hinted the central bank could authorise negative interest rates or buying assets from banks to hit its inflation target. Peter Praet told the Wall Street Journal:

If our mandate is at risk we are going to take all the measures that we think we should take to fulfil that mandate. That's a very clear signal. The balance sheet capacity of the central bank can also be used. This includes outright purchases that any central bank can do.

The ECB cut interest rates to 0.25% last week and kept the deposit rate at zero. Praet said:

On standard measures, interest rates, we still have room and that would also include the deposit facility.

Updated at 3.14pm GMT

3.01pm GMT

Over in Ireland, some good employment news. Henry McDonald, Ireland Correspondent, writes:

Belfast's iconic shipbuilding firm that constructed the Titanic has given Northern Ireland's economy a temporary boost with the creation of 600 short term skilled jobs.
Harland and Wolff, whose giant yellow cranes dominate the Belfast skyline, announced today that they are recruiting the extra skilled tradesmen to work on one of the largest oil rigs ever built in its shipyard.
The 360 ft tall Blackford Dolphin offshore drill platform is currently on its way from Brazil to Belfast where it will undergo maintenance work at the yard where the Titanic was made.

David McVeigh, head of sales and marketing at Harland and Wolff, said the contract was on such a large scale and completed within such a tight time frame, that the 600 additional workers had to be found in a relatively short period of time.

"Harland and Wolff continues to compete successfully in a sector which has seen competition grow," said McVeigh.

"Apart from being able to exceed stringent health and safety element requirements for such contracts, H&W is also capable of great flexibility which means we can put 600 contractors from electrical, welding, engineering and painting disciplines in place in a short time."

The shipyard now concentrates on maintaining and repairing oil rigs rather than ships. Its giant Samson and Goliath cranes will have to be moved out of their current positions along tracks to the end of the building dock for the estimated 50 days of work on the Blackford Dolphin rig.

2.49pm GMT

Our Data Blog has pulled together statistics on the unemployment figures:

The unemployment rate dropped from 7.8% in the three months to June to 7.6% – its lowest level in four years, but what has happened to the claimant count? Using the October 2013 figures from Nomis, the map shows the numbers by each local authority.

The data is here:

UK unemployment mapped

2.22pm GMT

The FTSE 100 is on course for its worse one day fall in months. It is 105 points or 1.57% lower which would be its biggest drop since 20 June, if it ends like this. On Wall Street, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is forecast to open around 90 points lower, so there will be no help for the bulls from that direction.

The falls are being driven by the feeling that central banks could finally start switching off the money taps, which have been providing support for the markets for what seems like forever. On Tuesday US Federal Reserve member Dennis Lockhart - seen as being in the centre as far as the policy debate goes - suggested there was a possibility the bank could reduce its $85bn a month bond buying programme at its December meeting. Most observers had still been banking on no change to the stimulus programme until next year.

Meanwhile, as we have been reporting this morning, the Bank of England may also raise rates sooner than had been anticipated.

2.06pm GMT

Back to the Bank of England....

On the Bank of England's raised growth forecasts, our economics correspondent Phillip Inman reports:

The Bank of England expects to consider raising interest rates in 2015, a year earlier than expected, following a sharp fall in unemployment.

But the bank tempered expectations of an early increase with the warning that the recovery remained fragile and rates could still remain low for several years.

Governor Mark Carney said he expected growth to remain modest over the next couple of years while the economy continues to be hampered by a weak banking sector and stumbling overseas markets.

Speaking after publication of the central bank's quarterly inflation report, Carney played down concerns that the current 0.5% base rate would rise before real incomes begin to rise and the recovery is secured.

"The economy is growing robustly as lifting uncertainty and thawing credit conditions start to unlock pent-up demand. But significant headwinds – both at home and abroad – remain, and there is a long way to go before the aftermath of the financial crisis has cleared and economic conditions normalise," he said in the report.

"That underpins the monetary policy committee's (MPC) intention to maintain the exceptionally stimulative stance of monetary policy until there has been a substantial reduction in the degree of economic slack."

In August the BoE said as part of its new policy of forward guidance that it would not consider raising interest rates before unemployment fell to 7%. MPC members agreed that unemployment was a strong indicator of slack in the economy. Figures for August show that rate has fallen to 7.6% following an unexpectedly sharp rise in job recruitment over the previous three months.

In response the BoE said there was now a three in five chance that the UK unemployment rate would hit 7% in mid-2015 compared to a previous prediction of late 2016.

Deputy governor Charlie Bean said forward guidance was still pointing to a rate rise later rather than sooner. He said: "The key message is that policy is not going to be related to growth rates but the elimination of slack."

Here's the full story: Interest rates could rise in 2015 – BoE

The other big news story of the day is the drop in UK unemployment, to a four-year low of 7.6%.

Economics editor Larry Elliott writes:

Britain's rising population means that a record number of people – 29.95 million – are in work but the employment rate remains lower than it was before the deep recession of 2008-09. The current rate of 71.8% compares with 73% at the peak in early 2008 but above the trough of 70.8% reached in 2011.

The bulk of the jobs created in the latest three months were full time but a record 1.46 million people were working part time because they could not find a full-time job. Unemployment as measured by the number of people out of work and claiming eligible benefits dropped by 41,700 in September to 1.3 million.

More here: Jobless rate moves towards Bank of England target

And that's a good moment to hand over Nick Fletcher, before trading begins on Wall Street. Shares are still lower in London, with the FTSE 100 down 107 points... GW

Updated at 2.07pm GMT

1.45pm GMT

As well as the departure of Sir Hector Sants, Barclays has also reported that chief operations and technology officer, Shaygan Kheradpir, is leaving the company.

Here's the bank's statement:

Hector Sants has been on sick leave since the beginning of October, suffering from stress and exhaustion. He has concluded that he will not be able to return to work in the near term. Consequently he has decided to resign from Barclays and not return from sick leave.

Shaygan Kheradpir, Chief Operations and Technology Officer, is leaving Barclays to take on a role as CEO for a company based in the United States.

An internal and external search will be launched for both posts. In the meantime Allen Meyer, Head of Compliance, Corporate and Investment Banking will act as Interim Head of Compliance and Government and Regulatory Relations. Darryl West, Barclays’ Chief Information Officer, will act as Interim Group Chief Operations and Technology Officer. In these posts both will join the Executive Committee and report to Group Chief Executive, Antony Jenkins.

Updated at 1.46pm GMT

1.33pm GMT

Sants leaves Barclays

Sir Hector Sants, the former head of the UK's Financial Services Authority, has stepped down from his role as head of compliance at Barclays, my colleague Jill Treanor reports.

This comes a month after Sants began a "leave of absence" after being diagnosed with exhaustion and stress. 

Updated at 1.34pm GMT

1.29pm GMT

EC begins review of German trade surplus

Over in Brussels, the European Commission has - as anticipated - launched an inquiry into the German trade surplus.

In a new report, the EC said it would launch an "in-depth review" of both Germany and Luxembourg.

It plans to:

better scrutinise their external position and analyse internal developments, and assess whether any of these countries is experiencing imbalances.

It explained that the German trade surplus has exceeded the EC's 'threshold' (6% of national GDP) each year since 2007, so it clearly isn't a short-term problem.

This means Germany becomes one of 16 Member States who are being probed for imbalances (many others face questions over current account deficits, losses of competitiveness and debt and deficit levels).

This chart shows the differences between EU member states:

Germany's defenders say it should not be blamed for running a successful export sector, and suggest that other countries could learn a few lessons.

Commission president José Manuel Barroso sounded conciliatory at a press briefing in Brussels, saying:

Europe needs more Germanys.

Bundesbank president Jens Weidmann has already warned that Germany shouldn't be penalised, according to this Reuters newsflash:

• WEIDMANN SAYS ANSWER TO GERMANY'S CURRENT ACCOUNT SURPLUS CANNOT BE TO MAKE GERMAN COMPANIES LESS COMPETITIVE 

Updated at 1.34pm GMT

12.55pm GMT

12.53pm GMT

Bank of England's report: What the experts say

Here's some economist reaction:

David Kern, chief economist at the British Chambers of Commerce:

We support Governor Carney’s statement that the pressure on living standards can only be addressed when productivity increases. Simply raising wages before this happens would make businesses uncompetitive and threaten the recovery.

Howard Archer of IHS Global Insight:

The message coming loud and clear from the Bank of England is that it remains in no hurry at all to raise interest rates despite the economy’s improved performance and a likely significantly faster fall in unemployment than the central bank had previously expected.

It is clear that the Bank of England wants to give the economy every chance to develop sustainable decent growth and not to risk choking it off by any premature increasing of interest rates.

Rob Wood of Berenberg Bank:

The BoE signalled its first rate hike might come in 2015, rather than late 2016 as it had previously said, in its quarterly forecast update this morning.....

We see a 70% chance that unemployment falls to the 7% threshold by Q3 2015, compared to the BoE’s 50% chance.

So while they have moved towards our view and the market, they still have some way to go. The risks are probably that the BoE is underestimating the speed at which the economy can recover. With loose policy, falling uncertainty and booming house prices, the recovery could snowball and more than 3% growth next year is not impossible. There are downside risks too of course, that we should not forget, but they seem to be diminishing.

12.40pm GMT

Market reaction

The pound has rallied by around 0.5% today, following the Bank of England's new forecasts and this morning's drop in UK unemployment (see 9.30am onwards).

It's gained three quarters of a cent, against the US dollar to $1.5977.

Shares, though, are down in London as traders anticipate monetary policy being tightened more quickly.

The FTSE 100 has dropped by 93 points, or 1.39%, to 6633.

Financial stocks are among the fallers -- with RSA Insurance down 3.8%, Standard Chartered down 3.4% and Barclays losing 3.1%.

12.24pm GMT

Bank of England quarterly inflation report, a summary

So, to quickly recap.

•The Bank of England has raised its economic forecasts, concluding that Britain's output will rise faster than expected this year and in 2014. This will help to pull down the UK unemployment rate, with a roughly 40% chance that it will be 7% by the end of next year.

• Governor Mark Carney said the UK recovery had "finally taken hold", but warned that it needs to become "strong and sustained" to get more people into work, and to drive wages higher.

For the first time in a long time you don't have to be an optimist to see the glass is half full. The recovery has finally taken hold.

This chart shows how the BoE sees more chance of the jobless rate hitting 7% soon:

• Carney defended his 'forward guidance' on interest rates, which states that borrowing costs won't rise until the jobless rate has hit 7%. He said the pledge had helped to sustain the recovery, and did not mean that a rate rise was inevitable once the 7% rate has been hit.

He said:

There was always going to be movement in the timing of when potentially the unemployment threshold was reached .. but what's important is two things.

One is what we learn between now and when that threshold is achieved, what we learn about the economy, what we learn about how much extra slack there is in the economy. And secondly what the conditions are when it's achieved and we're providing the confidence to businesses and households that we will not even begin to think about moving interest rates until that threshold is achieved.

• Carney was also asked about the UK housing market, and concerns of a bubble in London. He replied that the Bank is setting policy for the whole country, not "inside the Circle Line", adding:

In terms of housing valuation there are clearly areas in the country where valuation is very elevated. What we are seeing across the UK is the greatest price momentum is for houses that are towards the upper end of the valuation spectrum.

The bank, through the Financial Policy Committee, will be vigilant about potential risks there but we need to put the pickup in housing activity in perspective. Activity levels, while they've picked up, are still running at between two thirds or three quarters of historic averages in terms of whether its transactions or approvals, homebuilding, so there is some room for that to further pickup and that's the initial phase of this recovery.

• And the Bank is still cautious about the situation in the eurozone, even though the 'pall' of uncertainty over the future of the euro has mostly lifted. Carney said the UK central bank isn't expecting a big pick-up in demand from Europe.

Updated at 12.54pm GMT

11.47am GMT

And that's the end of the press conference - cue a brief burst of Beethoven* on the webcast feed.

* - 9th Symphony, 2nd movement, rather awesome

11.42am GMT

Several questions on the government's Help to Buy mortgage subsidy scheme.

Observer economics editor Heather Stewart asks about the Treasury Select Committee's concerns (they want the Bank of England to clarify its role in the scheme).

Carney says that the issue will be considered at the next meeting of the Financial Policy Committee (responsible for ensuring economic stability). He adds that the Bank has a range of ways to influence the housing market.

11.33am GMT

Kathryn Hopkins of The Times raises the issue of gender targets (the Bank of England's senior ranks are dominated by men).

Mark Carney replies that "it is an objective of this institution to increase the diversity of our junior ranks, and senior ranks".

Appointments to the senior ranks are made by others, he points out (the Treasury picks the governor, and the members of the rate-setting Monetary Policy Committee), but the Bank can increase diversity at all levels.

A review of the Bank's talent management and recruitment policies is underway, he adds, though he won't prejudge its conclusions

11.28am GMT

Asked about the eurozone, Mark Carney says that the Bank of England only expects "quite modest demand growth" in this major export market.

We do expect the removal, or reduction, of the pall of uncertainty that hung over businesses over the future of the eurozone, he adds.

But Threadneedle Street is not relying on any meaningful recovery in Europe to drive this forwards.

And that's why the GDP growth forecasts remain relatively modest compared to previous recoveries, he adds.

11.26am GMT

11.25am GMT

How much credit does Mark Carney take for the recent pick-up in the UK economy, asks Channel 4's Faisal Islam.

Governor Carney says that "our view is that forward guidance is helpful to sustain the recovery, that's why we did it."

You only see the value of it at events like today, and in meetings with people around the country. People understand that the Bank of England "needs to see sustained momentum and the slack picked up" before we would tighten monetary policy.

The government's Funding for Lending scheme is also helping to support the recovery and provide support for bank balance sheets, Carney adds.

Updated at 11.26am GMT

11.18am GMT

Should the Bank's Financial Policy Committee act on the house price levels in London, the main topic of conversation at dinner parties in the capital? 

Carney says the Bank is looking at the bigger picture:

We don't make policy for inside the Circle Line, we make it for the entire United Kingdom.

And at this stage, the Bank isn't very worried about the housing market.

He argues that expectations of future earnings can drive increased consumption levels, rather than the fact that people's houses are worth more (which doesn't deliver a real 'wealth effect' unless people can unlock the value). 

11.07am GMT

What would a more normal economy look like? 

Mark Carney says that as the economy 'heals', the natural rate of unemployment should return to the pre-crisis levels of around 5%.

But to be a sustainable, we need to see growth in real wages (ie, pay rises need to beat inflation not lag behind it) to sustain consumption growth.

Updated at 11.07am GMT

11.05am GMT

Our economics editor Larry Elliott calls the Bank of England's forecasting record to account.

 Larry asks:

You failed to spot the recession in 2008, you failed to spot the flat-lining economy in 2010, and now you've failed to spot the stronger recovery. How can we have any faith in the forecasts that underpin forward guidance?

Carney defends the Bank's record, says that it's confident that it's predictions are on the right path. He adds, though, that he's trying to make the forecasts more transparent to that doubters can better understand the bank's thinking.

He then bats the question over to chief economist Spencer Dale -- who says that weaker global demand was one reason the Bank's UK growth forecasts were too optimistic in the past.

Dale also argues that the real power of forward guidance is that people understand the Bank's approach to monetary policy, rather than its forecasts.

10.58am GMT

Carney defends forward guidance

What on earth is the point of forward guidance on interest rates, asks Chris Giles of the FT, given the dramatic changes in the Bank of England's predictions. 

Imagine a world without forward guidance, replies Mark Carney. We've had an unexpectedly strong recovery - stronger than most analysts expected.

If forward guidance wasn't introduced in August, the discussion would be 'is the Bank going to raise interest rates today'. No-one is asking that question today...

...and rightly so, Carney adds. A rate rise would mean the bank would "take a recovery that has finally taken hold and pull the rug out from under it".

10.53am GMT

Bank of England: the recovery is finally taken hold

Here's the key quote from the Bank of England's report, declaring that the British recovery is, at last, underway:

In the United Kingdom, recovery has finally taken hold. The economy is growing robustly as lifting uncertainty and thawing credit conditions start to unlock pent-up demand.

But significant headwinds — both at home and abroad — remain, and there is a long way to go before the aftermath of the financial crisis has cleared and economic conditions normalise. That underpins the MPC’s intention to maintain the exceptionally stimulative stance of monetary policy until there has been a substantial reduction in the degree of economic slack. 

The pace at which that slack is eroded, and the durability of the recovery, will depend on the extent to which productivity picks up alongside demand. Productivity growth has risen in recent quarters, although unemployment has fallen by slightly more than expected on the back of strong output growth.

10.50am GMT

The full quarterly inflation report is online here.

10.50am GMT

What can the Bank of England do to close the gap between wages and inflation, asks Sky's Ed Conway.

Carney replies that it is important that the recovery persists, and "we need a pickup in business investment" too.

The Bank's pledge to keep interest rates at record lows at least until the jobless rate is 7% will also help, he adds.

10.45am GMT

As expected, Mark Carney is having to defend his forward guidance policy on interest rates.

Asked how people and businesses are supposed to plan for the future if the bank's forecasts change so much, governor Carney explains that his priority is to "provide confidence" that borrowing costs won't rise until the recovery is secured.

Interest rates won't immediately rise when the jobless rate hits 7%, he insists.

10.43am GMT

The Bank of England's Q&A is being webcast here.

10.41am GMT

Mark Carney is telling reporters in London that:

For the first time in a long time, you don't need to be an optimist to see that the glass is half full. The recovery has taken hold.

He's explaining that the Bank of England's job is to help secure the recovery, and make it strong enough to get more people back into work. 

Updated at 10.47am GMT

10.39am GMT

The Bank of England has also raised its growth forecasts.

It expects GDP to rise by 1.6% for 2013 as a whole, up from 1.4%.

In 2014, it expects growth of 2.8%, up from 2.5% in the August report.

It still expects growth of 2.3% in 2015.

10.36am GMT

Bank of England releases quarterly inflation report

The Bank of England has just released its latest quarterly report on the UK economy.

And it's raised its economic forecasts, saying that the unemployment rate will fall faster than it expected three months ago. There is a "two in five chance" that it could be 7% at the end of 2014, Mark Carney says.

However, that doesn't mean interest rates would immediately rise (7% being the target in the Bank's forward guidance). 

It also believes that the inflation rate will fall to the 2% target faster than it thought in August.

Here's the Reuters newsflashes: 

• BANK OF ENGLAND NOV INFLATION REPORT - UK RECOVERY HAS FINALLY TAKEN HOLD, ECONOMY GROWING ROBUSTLY BUT SIGNIFICANT HEADWINDS REMAIN 

• BOE - MPC INTENDS TO KEEP EXCEPTIONALLY STIMULATIVE POLICY STANCE UNTIL SLACK HAS REDUCED SUBSTANTIALLY 13-Nov-2013

• BOE - UNEMPLOYMENT LIKELY TO FALL MORE QUICKLY THAN FORECAST IN AUGUST, HITTING 7 PCT THRESHOLD WILL NOT NECESSARILY TRIGGER RATE RISE 

• BOE INFLATION REPORT SAYS MPC SEES 41 PCT CHANCE OF 7 PCT UNEMPLOYMENT AT END-2014, 57 PCT AT END-2015, 68 PCT AT END-2016 BASED ON MARKET INTEREST RATES 

10.29am GMT

10.28am GMT

The recovery in the UK unemployment rate comes as the Bank of England prepares to release its latest Quarterly Inflation Report (in just a couple of minutes).

Having pinned UK interest rates to the jobless rate, will Mark Carney now say that the recovery is accelerating faster than he expected? We're about to find out....

10.24am GMT

UK unemployment: what the politicians say

Here's the political reaction to the news that Britain's unemployment rate has fallen to 7.6%, but that pay remains well below inflation (see 9.31am onwards for all the details).

Minister for Employment Esther McVey

This Government is delivering on its promise to rebalance the economy, promote job creation, and support people to get off benefits and into work.

Today's figures show that the number of people in work has risen by more than a million under this Government, with the growth driven by full-time private sector jobs. 

At the same time, the number of people claiming the main out-of-work benefits has fallen by almost half a million. There's more work to do, and we are not complacent, but these are all very positive signs.

Rachel Reeves MP, Labour’s Shadow Work and Pensions Secretary

Today’s fall in unemployment is welcome, but families facing a cost-of-living crisis need a recovery that benefits them, and these figures show we are still far from achieving that.

Prices have now risen much faster than wages for 40 of the 41 months since David Cameron became Prime Minister. On average working people are now over £1,600 a year worse off under this out-of-touch Government.

The employment figures give no cause for complacency. The number of people who want to work full-time but are stuck on part-time hours is at a record high. And youth unemployment is still at unacceptable and unaffordable levels with almost a million young people still out of work, while the number of young people unemployed for a year or more has gone up by 7,000 this quarter.

The Tory-led Government’s Work Programme and Youth Contract are failing – they should adopt Labour’s compulsory jobs guarantee, funded by repeating the tax on bank bonuses, and limiting pension tax relief for the very highest earners. This would guarantee real paid work for young people unemployed for a year, or adults unemployed for two years – work they would have to take or lose benefits.

10.21am GMT

Incidentally, we've just learned that September was a less cheery month for the eurozone. Factory output fell by 0.5%, rather worse than expected.

10.19am GMT

Now this is interesting.... the ONS has also released an unofficial snapshot of the UK labour market just for September.

It's more informal than the official data -- "not designated as National Statistics" as the jargon has it.

But with that caveat duly noted.... the data shows that the jobless rate was just 7.1% in September itself (compared to 7.6% for the July-September quarter). It's online here....

That's much closer to the 7% target which the Bank of England has set as a milestone before interest rates could rise. 

10.13am GMT

Rob Wood of Berenberg Bank says unemployment is falling faster than economists, or the Bank of England, expected -- but he is also concerned that wage growth is so weak.

Wood comments:

There is a lot of good news in this release for the UK economy. Stonking job gains show the UK is recovering rapidly.

At the same time those jobs gains are not cutting unemployment as fast as might be expected because the workforce is rising rapidly.

Unlike in the US, the UK participation rate is rising. People are competing for jobs rather than giving up and leaving the workforce. That is keeping wage growth very subdued.

10.10am GMT

The wage squeeze continues....

Many analysts concerned by the lack of progress in pay (with total weekly earnings up just 0.7% annually).

10.07am GMT

As this graph shows, the UK unemployment rate has now dropped to its lowest in over four years - it hit 7.6% in May 2009, during the recession sparked by the financial crisis:

Updated at 10.07am GMT

9.56am GMT

This chart shows how the rise in the labour force was split between men and women, and between full-timer and part-time staff:

9.54am GMT

At 29.95 million people, the UK workforce is now at a record high having jumped by 177,000 in the July-September quarter. 

However, this partly reflects increased population levels. The employment rate of 71.8% is not at a record high -- as this graph shows, it's still below its pre-crisis levels:

It's moving the right way, though....

9.49am GMT

While the fall in the headline jobless rate is clearly welcome, the detail of the ONS report paints a more sober picture.

For example, the number of people working part-time because they can't get full-time employment is at a record high.

According to the ONS there were 1.46 million employees and self-employed people who were working part-time because they could not find a full-time job, the highest figure since records began in 1992.

9.43am GMT

The full report from the Office for National Statistics is online here:

Labour Market Statistics, November 2013

9.41am GMT

But while unemployment is down, pay packets are not yet feeling the benefits.

Total pay, including bonuses, rose by 0.7% annually in September -- down from 0.8% in August. That's dwarfed by the 2.2% rise in inflation over the last year in Britain.

Average pay fell year-on-year in the public sector.

The ONS reported:

Average weekly earnings for the private sector increased by 1.1% but average weekly earnings for the public sector fell by 0.4%. 

In September 2013 average pay including bonus payments in the private sector was £473 a week, £14 a week lower than the public sector figure of £487 a week. However, excluding publicly owned financial corporations, average weekly pay in the public sector was only £3 a week higher than for the private sector, at £476 a week.

9.36am GMT

The UK claimant count is also down -- dropping by 41,700 people in October. That takes the claimant count rate down to 3.9%.

Updated at 9.36am GMT

9.33am GMT

The total number of people in work across the UK rose by 177,000 in the three months to September, taking the total to 29.953 million. That's the biggest jump since the June to August quarter.

Updated at 9.34am GMT

9.31am GMT

UK unemployment rate falls

Breaking: the UK unemployment rate has fallen to 7.6% in the three months to September.

The number of people out of work fell by 48,000 to 2.466m in the quarter, which Reuters says is the lowest level in three years.

More to follow....

9.17am GMT

UK unemployment data due soon

We get the latest UK unemployment data in less than 15 minutes time. As mentioned at the start, economists expect:

• a drop in the claimant count of around 30,000 people in October (compared with 41k last month) 

• a rise in the number of people in work in the three months to September, of around 113,000

• No change to the unemployment rate, of 7.7% [which is crucial to UK monetary policy given the Bank of England's pledge not to raise rates till it hits 7%] 

• Another fall in real pay, with average weekly earnings expected to have risen by just 0.7% over the last year.

In other words, some signs of recovery in the labour market, but no relief to the squeeze on living standards and wages.

The youth unemployment data will also be scrutinised, with a new report warning that the jobless rate among young people has still risen despite the UK economy returning to growth.

9.05am GMT

Bad economic data from the Netherlands -- retail sales tumbled by 6.1% year-on-year in September.

8.54am GMT

European stock markets are in the red this morning, with the FTSE 100 shedding 47 points or 0.7%.

Traders are blaming nervousness ahead of the Bank of England's inflation report (what will Mark Carney say about growth prospects and rate rises?), and another bout of jitters over when the US Federal Reserve will start to slow its own stimulus programme.

There's also a knock-on effect from Asia. China's stock market shed 2% following the conclusion of the Beijing government's Plenary meeting where leaders pledged to give the markets a "decisive role" in the country's economic future.

Mike van Dulken of Accendo Markets says traders are

disappointed by the rather general/vague Chinese statement in terms of its plan for the next decade.

Updated at 8.54am GMT

8.41am GMT

In the corporate world, Sainsbury's is getting into the early festive spirit with a 7% jump in profits, the top of analyst forecasts.

The supermarket chain also reported that its market share was at its highest for a decade, but remained cautious about UK economic prospects.

Phil Dorrell, director of the retail consultants Retail Remedy, reckons "The fairytale continues at Sainsbury's", and predicts it will do well this Christmas.

More here: Sainsbury's profit rise 7% as own-brand and online sales thrive

8.39am GMT

Robin Bew of the Economist Intelligence Unit tweets that yesterday's drop in UK inflation, to 2.2%, gives Mark Carney and colleagues a little more room to manoeuvre.

And as our economics editor Larry Elliott wrote yesterday, spending power is on the wane in many countries.

Inflation fall shows effects of spending power squeeze

8.21am GMT

Speaking of the eurozone, we get also industrial production data for September at 10am -- economists expect a 0.3% drop month-on-month.

Germany's top central banker, Jens Weidmann, is giving a speech around noon GMT. Let's hope he comments on last week's ECB interest rate cut, given the Bundesbank chief is understood to have opposed it.

Greece's finance minister, Yannis Stournaras, meanwhile is reported to be in Brussels - perhaps preparing for tomorrow's Eurogroup meeting of finance ministers.

Yesterday, Stournaras denied that the Athens government and its troika inspectors were "miles" apart in their assessment of Greece's performance against its bailout programme. It's just meters, he insisted. 

8.13am GMT

Spain reports deflation in October

Spain's annual inflation rate turned negative last month, according to new data that will heighten concerns that parts of the eurozone are slipping into deflation.

The latest inflation data showed that the Spanish consumer prices index fell by 0.1% in October, on an annual basis. On a monthly basis, the CPI rose by 0.4%. 

On an 'EU harmonised basis', prices were flat year-on-year. 

We have seen a steady stream of low inflation rates recently (German's CPI fell to 1.2%), while the cost of living fell by 2.0% in Greece last month. Understandable, given sluggish demand, weak European growth and cash-strapped consumers.

Updated at 8.24am GMT

7.56am GMT

City traders are predicting the blue-chip Footsie index will drop by around 0.6%, when trading begins in a few minutes.

7.52am GMT

Much was made of Mark Carney's Canadian background when he was named as Sir Mervyn King's successor. The FT has now discovered that he's also the proud holder of Irish citizenship too:

Chris Giles reports:

Since his arrival as governor of the Bank of England in July Mark Carney has had the luck of the Irish, enjoying rising growth, falling unemployment and rapidly moderating inflation.

That cannot have been much of a surprise to the BoE or Treasury as on Tuesday night both confirmed that the Canadian running the old Lady of Threadneedle Street has also held Irish citizenship since 1988 when he started working for Goldman Sachs in London.

More here: Mark Carney brings luck of the Irish to BoE

And on the FT's front page:

Updated at 7.52am GMT

7.31am GMT

Bank of England and UK unemployment data

Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of events across the economy, the financial markets, the eurozone and the business world.

UK economics is centre-stage today, with the release of fresh unemployment data (at 9.30am) followed by the Bank of England's quarterly inflation report (from 10.30am). 

And what a difference three months makes. Back on August 7, governor Mark Carney pushed the Bank of England into a bold new era by setting 'forward guidance' on interest rates. Effectively he pledged that borrowing costs won't rise until the UK jobless rate drops to 7% (from 7.7% a month ago), which Carney didn't see happening until 2016.

Since then, a rich seam of solid economic data has shown that Britain's economy is performing better than most analysts thought in August. So the Bank is likely to upgrade its growth forecasts, and could also predict that unemployment will fall faster than previously expected.

And that could fuel predictions that UK interest rates will finally rise from their record low of 0.5% somewhat earlier than 2016.

The unemployment data, meanwhile, is expected to show another drop in the number of people signing on for the Jobseeker's Allowance in October. The headline jobless rate is expected to stay at 7.7% for the three months to September.

Michael Hewson of CMC helpfully rounds up the recent figures:

The latest unemployment numbers look set to show the ILO September unemployment rate stuck at 7.7% despite double digit falls in jobless claims numbers for the last four months.

Claims numbers for October are expected to show another double digit decline of 33k, following on from declines of 41.7k, 32.6k, 29.2k and 21.2k, in previous months.

But with pay still lagging behind inflation (which fell to 2.2% yesterday), it may not feel like a recovery to many.

We'll be tracking all the events through the day...

Updated at 7.42am GMT
fields.bodyText: European markets have ended on the back foot, mainly due to continuing concerns that central banks - particularly the US Federal Reserve and the Bank of England - might soon turn off the money taps. Investors had expected the Fed to begin winding down its $85bn a month bond buying programme next year, but there are growing hints it might end sooner. Meanwhile the UK economy appears to be growing more strongly than expected, bringing forward the prospect of rising interest rates. Conversely, the European Central Bank could yet buy assets from banks and sanction negative deposit rates, according to board member Peter Praet. So here are the market movements: • The FTSE 100 is down 96.79 points or 1.44% at 6630.00, its biggest one day fall since 15 August • Germany's Dax has dropped 0.24% to 9054.83 • France's Cac closed 0.56% lower at 4239.94 • Italy's FTSE MIB fell 1.43% to 18,733.02 • Spain's Ibex ended down 0.33% at 9675.2 On Wall Street, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is currently 50 points or 0.32% lower. On that note, it's time to close up for the evening. Thanks for all the comments, and we'll be back tomorrow for another busy day. Something to please Mark Carney (probably): Meanwhile, in Madrid...... Over in Greece, the country is said to be on track to balance its budget this year. According to deputy finance minister Christos Staikouras, the recovery has been helped by a recovery in tax revenues. AP has the story: Staikouras said the country was expected to post a budget surplus of about €345m before interest payments this year a key target set by bailout lenders. The January-October balance stood at €1.1bn, Staikouras said, after traditionally weak tax revenues came in €250m above target, at €35.59bn for the 10-month period. "It seems that the country will meet its national target. Of course, this is due to the enormous sacrifices made by Greeks, unprecedented in post-war Europe," Staikouras said. Unemployment in Greece is nearing 28%, amid rapidly increasing poverty due to years of austerity measures imposed in exchange for the bailout program worth €240bn. Greece is currently in talks with bailout inspectors to try and resolve a disagreement over 2014 budget cuts and how to ease government protection for distressed mortgages. The left-wing opposition Syriza described the negotiations as a sham. "These negotiations with the Europeans are a charade. The (government) is in fact reciting its loyalty to its lenders," a party statement said. "Its goal was and remains the resolute implementation of bailout commitments with no consideration for the social cost." The euro has come under pressure after an ECB board member hinted the central bank could authorise negative interest rates or buying assets from banks to hit its inflation target. Peter Praet told the Wall Street Journal: If our mandate is at risk we are going to take all the measures that we think we should take to fulfil that mandate. That's a very clear signal. The balance sheet capacity of the central bank can also be used. This includes outright purchases that any central bank can do. The ECB cut interest rates to 0.25% last week and kept the deposit rate at zero. Praet said: On standard measures, interest rates, we still have room and that would also include the deposit facility. Over in Ireland, some good employment news. Henry McDonald, Ireland Correspondent, writes: Belfast's iconic shipbuilding firm that constructed the Titanic has given Northern Ireland's economy a temporary boost with the creation of 600 short term skilled jobs. Harland and Wolff, whose giant yellow cranes dominate the Belfast skyline, announced today that they are recruiting the extra skilled tradesmen to work on one of the largest oil rigs ever built in its shipyard. The 360 ft tall Blackford Dolphin offshore drill platform is currently on its way from Brazil to Belfast where it will undergo maintenance work at the yard where the Titanic was made. David McVeigh, head of sales and marketing at Harland and Wolff, said the contract was on such a large scale and completed within such a tight time frame, that the 600 additional workers had to be found in a relatively short period of time. "Harland and Wolff continues to compete successfully in a sector which has seen competition grow," said McVeigh. "Apart from being able to exceed stringent health and safety element requirements for such contracts, H&W is also capable of great flexibility which means we can put 600 contractors from electrical, welding, engineering and painting disciplines in place in a short time." The shipyard now concentrates on maintaining and repairing oil rigs rather than ships. Its giant Samson and Goliath cranes will have to be moved out of their current positions along tracks to the end of the building dock for the estimated 50 days of work on the Blackford Dolphin rig. Our Data Blog has pulled together statistics on the unemployment figures: The unemployment rate dropped from 7.8% in the three months to June to 7.6% – its lowest level in four years, but what has happened to the claimant count? Using the October 2013 figures from Nomis, the map shows the numbers by each local authority. The data is here: UK unemployment mapped The FTSE 100 is on course for its worse one day fall in months. It is 105 points or 1.57% lower which would be its biggest drop since 20 June, if it ends like this. On Wall Street, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is forecast to open around 90 points lower, so there will be no help for the bulls from that direction. The falls are being driven by the feeling that central banks could finally start switching off the money taps, which have been providing support for the markets for what seems like forever. On Tuesday US Federal Reserve member Dennis Lockhart - seen as being in the centre as far as the policy debate goes - suggested there was a possibility the bank could reduce its $85bn a month bond buying programme at its December meeting. Most observers had still been banking on no change to the stimulus programme until next year. Meanwhile, as we have been reporting this morning, the Bank of England may also raise rates sooner than had been anticipated. On the Bank of England's raised growth forecasts, our economics correspondent Phillip Inman reports: The Bank of England expects to consider raising interest rates in 2015, a year earlier than expected, following a sharp fall in unemployment. But the bank tempered expectations of an early increase with the warning that the recovery remained fragile and rates could still remain low for several years. Governor Mark Carney said he expected growth to remain modest over the next couple of years while the economy continues to be hampered by a weak banking sector and stumbling overseas markets. Speaking after publication of the central bank's quarterly inflation report, Carney played down concerns that the current 0.5% base rate would rise before real incomes begin to rise and the recovery is secured. "The economy is growing robustly as lifting uncertainty and thawing credit conditions start to unlock pent-up demand. But significant headwinds – both at home and abroad – remain, and there is a long way to go before the aftermath of the financial crisis has cleared and economic conditions normalise," he said in the report. "That underpins the monetary policy committee's (MPC) intention to maintain the exceptionally stimulative stance of monetary policy until there has been a substantial reduction in the degree of economic slack." In August the BoE said as part of its new policy of forward guidance that it would not consider raising interest rates before unemployment fell to 7%. MPC members agreed that unemployment was a strong indicator of slack in the economy. Figures for August show that rate has fallen to 7.6% following an unexpectedly sharp rise in job recruitment over the previous three months. In response the BoE said there was now a three in five chance that the UK unemployment rate would hit 7% in mid-2015 compared to a previous prediction of late 2016. Deputy governor Charlie Bean said forward guidance was still pointing to a rate rise later rather than sooner. He said: "The key message is that policy is not going to be related to growth rates but the elimination of slack." Here's the full story: Interest rates could rise in 2015 – BoE The other big news story of the day is the drop in UK unemployment, to a four-year low of 7.6%. Economics editor Larry Elliott writes: Britain's rising population means that a record number of people – 29.95 million – are in work but the employment rate remains lower than it was before the deep recession of 2008-09. The current rate of 71.8% compares with 73% at the peak in early 2008 but above the trough of 70.8% reached in 2011. The bulk of the jobs created in the latest three months were full time but a record 1.46 million people were working part time because they could not find a full-time job. Unemployment as measured by the number of people out of work and claiming eligible benefits dropped by 41,700 in September to 1.3 million. More here: Jobless rate moves towards Bank of England target And that's a good moment to hand over Nick Fletcher, before trading begins on Wall Street. Shares are still lower in London, with the FTSE 100 down 107 points... GW As well as the departure of Sir Hector Sants, Barclays has also reported that chief operations and technology officer, Shaygan Kheradpir, is leaving the company. Here's the bank's statement: Hector Sants has been on sick leave since the beginning of October, suffering from stress and exhaustion. He has concluded that he will not be able to return to work in the near term. Consequently he has decided to resign from Barclays and not return from sick leave. Shaygan Kheradpir, Chief Operations and Technology Officer, is leaving Barclays to take on a role as CEO for a company based in the United States. An internal and external search will be launched for both posts. In the meantime Allen Meyer, Head of Compliance, Corporate and Investment Banking will act as Interim Head of Compliance and Government and Regulatory Relations. Darryl West, Barclays’ Chief Information Officer, will act as Interim Group Chief Operations and Technology Officer. In these posts both will join the Executive Committee and report to Group Chief Executive, Antony Jenkins. Sir Hector Sants, the former head of the UK's Financial Services Authority, has stepped down from his role as head of compliance at Barclays, my colleague Jill Treanor reports. This comes a month after Sants began a "leave of absence" after being diagnosed with exhaustion and stress. Over in Brussels, the European Commission has - as anticipated - launched an inquiry into the German trade surplus. In a new report, the EC said it would launch an "in-depth review" of both Germany and Luxembourg. It plans to: better scrutinise their external position and analyse internal developments, and assess whether any of these countries is experiencing imbalances. It explained that the German trade surplus has exceeded the EC's 'threshold' (6% of national GDP) each year since 2007, so it clearly isn't a short-term problem. This means Germany becomes one of 16 Member States who are being probed for imbalances (many others face questions over current account deficits, losses of competitiveness and debt and deficit levels). This chart shows the differences between EU member states: Germany's defenders say it should not be blamed for running a successful export sector, and suggest that other countries could learn a few lessons. Commission president José Manuel Barroso sounded conciliatory at a press briefing in Brussels, saying: Europe needs more Germanys. Bundesbank president Jens Weidmann has already warned that Germany shouldn't be penalised, according to this Reuters newsflash: • WEIDMANN SAYS ANSWER TO GERMANY'S CURRENT ACCOUNT SURPLUS CANNOT BE TO MAKE GERMAN COMPANIES LESS COMPETITIVE Here's some economist reaction: David Kern, chief economist at the British Chambers of Commerce: We support Governor Carney’s statement that the pressure on living standards can only be addressed when productivity increases. Simply raising wages before this happens would make businesses uncompetitive and threaten the recovery. Howard Archer of IHS Global Insight: The message coming loud and clear from the Bank of England is that it remains in no hurry at all to raise interest rates despite the economy’s improved performance and a likely significantly faster fall in unemployment than the central bank had previously expected. It is clear that the Bank of England wants to give the economy every chance to develop sustainable decent growth and not to risk choking it off by any premature increasing of interest rates. Rob Wood of Berenberg Bank: The BoE signalled its first rate hike might come in 2015, rather than late 2016 as it had previously said, in its quarterly forecast update this morning..... We see a 70% chance that unemployment falls to the 7% threshold by Q3 2015, compared to the BoE’s 50% chance. So while they have moved towards our view and the market, they still have some way to go. The risks are probably that the BoE is underestimating the speed at which the economy can recover. With loose policy, falling uncertainty and booming house prices, the recovery could snowball and more than 3% growth next year is not impossible. There are downside risks too of course, that we should not forget, but they seem to be diminishing. The pound has rallied by around 0.5% today, following the Bank of England's new forecasts and this morning's drop in UK unemployment (see 9.30am onwards). It's gained three quarters of a cent, against the US dollar to $1.5977. Shares, though, are down in London as traders anticipate monetary policy being tightened more quickly. The FTSE 100 has dropped by 93 points, or 1.39%, to 6633. Financial stocks are among the fallers -- with RSA Insurance down 3.8%, Standard Chartered down 3.4% and Barclays losing 3.1%. So, to quickly recap. •The Bank of England has raised its economic forecasts, concluding that Britain's output will rise faster than expected this year and in 2014. This will help to pull down the UK unemployment rate, with a roughly 40% chance that it will be 7% by the end of next year. • Governor Mark Carney said the UK recovery had "finally taken hold", but warned that it needs to become "strong and sustained" to get more people into work, and to drive wages higher. For the first time in a long time you don't have to be an optimist to see the glass is half full. The recovery has finally taken hold. This chart shows how the BoE sees more chance of the jobless rate hitting 7% soon: • Carney defended his 'forward guidance' on interest rates, which states that borrowing costs won't rise until the jobless rate has hit 7%. He said the pledge had helped to sustain the recovery, and did not mean that a rate rise was inevitable once the 7% rate has been hit. He said: There was always going to be movement in the timing of when potentially the unemployment threshold was reached .. but what's important is two things. One is what we learn between now and when that threshold is achieved, what we learn about the economy, what we learn about how much extra slack there is in the economy. And secondly what the conditions are when it's achieved and we're providing the confidence to businesses and households that we will not even begin to think about moving interest rates until that threshold is achieved. • Carney was also asked about the UK housing market, and concerns of a bubble in London. He replied that the Bank is setting policy for the whole country, not "inside the Circle Line", adding: In terms of housing valuation there are clearly areas in the country where valuation is very elevated. What we are seeing across the UK is the greatest price momentum is for houses that are towards the upper end of the valuation spectrum. The bank, through the Financial Policy Committee, will be vigilant about potential risks there but we need to put the pickup in housing activity in perspective. Activity levels, while they've picked up, are still running at between two thirds or three quarters of historic averages in terms of whether its transactions or approvals, homebuilding, so there is some room for that to further pickup and that's the initial phase of this recovery. • And the Bank is still cautious about the situation in the eurozone, even though the 'pall' of uncertainty over the future of the euro has mostly lifted. Carney said the UK central bank isn't expecting a big pick-up in demand from Europe. And that's the end of the press conference - cue a brief burst of Beethoven* on the webcast feed. * - 9th Symphony, 2nd movement, rather awesome Several questions on the government's Help to Buy mortgage subsidy scheme. Observer economics editor Heather Stewart asks about the Treasury Select Committee's concerns (they want the Bank of England to clarify its role in the scheme). Carney says that the issue will be considered at the next meeting of the Financial Policy Committee (responsible for ensuring economic stability). He adds that the Bank has a range of ways to influence the housing market. Kathryn Hopkins of The Times raises the issue of gender targets (the Bank of England's senior ranks are dominated by men). Mark Carney replies that "it is an objective of this institution to increase the diversity of our junior ranks, and senior ranks". Appointments to the senior ranks are made by others, he points out (the Treasury picks the governor, and the members of the rate-setting Monetary Policy Committee), but the Bank can increase diversity at all levels. A review of the Bank's talent management and recruitment policies is underway, he adds, though he won't prejudge its conclusions Asked about the eurozone, Mark Carney says that the Bank of England only expects "quite modest demand growth" in this major export market. We do expect the removal, or reduction, of the pall of uncertainty that hung over businesses over the future of the eurozone, he adds. But Threadneedle Street is not relying on any meaningful recovery in Europe to drive this forwards. And that's why the GDP growth forecasts remain relatively modest compared to previous recoveries, he adds. How much credit does Mark Carney take for the recent pick-up in the UK economy, asks Channel 4's Faisal Islam. Governor Carney says that "our view is that forward guidance is helpful to sustain the recovery, that's why we did it." You only see the value of it at events like today, and in meetings with people around the country. People understand that the Bank of England "needs to see sustained momentum and the slack picked up" before we would tighten monetary policy. The government's Funding for Lending scheme is also helping to support the recovery and provide support for bank balance sheets, Carney adds. Should the Bank's Financial Policy Committee act on the house price levels in London, the main topic of conversation at dinner parties in the capital? Carney says the Bank is looking at the bigger picture: We don't make policy for inside the Circle Line, we make it for the entire United Kingdom. And at this stage, the Bank isn't very worried about the housing market. He argues that expectations of future earnings can drive increased consumption levels, rather than the fact that people's houses are worth more (which doesn't deliver a real 'wealth effect' unless people can unlock the value). What would a more normal economy look like? Mark Carney says that as the economy 'heals', the natural rate of unemployment should return to the pre-crisis levels of around 5%. But to be a sustainable, we need to see growth in real wages (ie, pay rises need to beat inflation not lag behind it) to sustain consumption growth. Our economics editor Larry Elliott calls the Bank of England's forecasting record to account. Larry asks: You failed to spot the recession in 2008, you failed to spot the flat-lining economy in 2010, and now you've failed to spot the stronger recovery. How can we have any faith in the forecasts that underpin forward guidance? Carney defends the Bank's record, says that it's confident that it's predictions are on the right path. He adds, though, that he's trying to make the forecasts more transparent to that doubters can better understand the bank's thinking. He then bats the question over to chief economist Spencer Dale -- who says that weaker global demand was one reason the Bank's UK growth forecasts were too optimistic in the past. Dale also argues that the real power of forward guidance is that people understand the Bank's approach to monetary policy, rather than its forecasts. What on earth is the point of forward guidance on interest rates, asks Chris Giles of the FT, given the dramatic changes in the Bank of England's predictions. Imagine a world without forward guidance, replies Mark Carney. We've had an unexpectedly strong recovery - stronger than most analysts expected. If forward guidance wasn't introduced in August, the discussion would be 'is the Bank going to raise interest rates today'. No-one is asking that question today... ...and rightly so, Carney adds. A rate rise would mean the bank would "take a recovery that has finally taken hold and pull the rug out from under it". Here's the key quote from the Bank of England's report, declaring that the British recovery is, at last, underway: In the United Kingdom, recovery has finally taken hold. The economy is growing robustly as lifting uncertainty and thawing credit conditions start to unlock pent-up demand. But significant headwinds — both at home and abroad — remain, and there is a long way to go before the aftermath of the financial crisis has cleared and economic conditions normalise. That underpins the MPC’s intention to maintain the exceptionally stimulative stance of monetary policy until there has been a substantial reduction in the degree of economic slack. Carney replies that it is important that the recovery persists, and "we need a pickup in business investment" too. The Bank's pledge to keep interest rates at record lows at least until the jobless rate is 7% will also help, he adds. As expected, Mark Carney is having to defend his forward guidance policy on interest rates. Asked how people and businesses are supposed to plan for the future if the bank's forecasts change so much, governor Carney explains that his priority is to "provide confidence" that borrowing costs won't rise until the recovery is secured. Interest rates won't immediately rise when the jobless rate hits 7%, he insists. The Bank of England's Q&A is being webcast here. Mark Carney is telling reporters in London that: For the first time in a long time, you don't need to be an optimist to see that the glass is half full. The recovery has taken hold. He's explaining that the Bank of England's job is to help secure the recovery, and make it strong enough to get more people back into work. The Bank of England has also raised its growth forecasts. It expects GDP to rise by 1.6% for 2013 as a whole, up from 1.4%. In 2014, it expects growth of 2.8%, up from 2.5% in the August report. It still expects growth of 2.3% in 2015. The Bank of England has just released its latest quarterly report on the UK economy. And it's raised its economic forecasts, saying that the unemployment rate will fall faster than it expected three months ago. There is a "two in five chance" that it could be 7% at the end of 2014, Mark Carney says. However, that doesn't mean interest rates would immediately rise (7% being the target in the Bank's forward guidance). It also believes that the inflation rate will fall to the 2% target faster than it thought in August. At the same time, the number of people claiming the main out-of-work benefits has fallen by almost half a million. There's more work to do, and we are not complacent, but these are all very positive signs. Now this is interesting.... the ONS has also released an unofficial snapshot of the UK labour market just for September. But with that caveat duly noted.... the data shows that the jobless rate was just 7.1% in September itself (compared to 7.6% for the July-September quarter). It's online here.... Bad economic data from the Netherlands -- retail sales tumbled by 6.1% year-on-year in September. European stock markets are in the red this morning, with the FTSE 100 shedding 47 points or 0.7%. Traders are blaming nervousness ahead of the Bank of England's inflation report (what will Mark Carney say about growth prospects and rate rises?), and another bout of jitters over when the US Federal Reserve will start to slow its own stimulus programme. Mike van Dulken of Accendo Markets says traders are disappointed by the rather general/vague Chinese statement in terms of its plan for the next decade. The supermarket chain also reported that its market share was at its highest for a decade, but remained cautious about UK economic prospects. Phil Dorrell, director of the retail consultants Retail Remedy, reckons "The fairytale continues at Sainsbury's", and predicts it will do well this Christmas. Germany's top central banker, Jens Weidmann, is giving a speech around noon GMT. Let's hope he comments on last week's ECB interest rate cut, given the Bundesbank chief is understood to have opposed it. Greece's finance minister, Yannis Stournaras, meanwhile is reported to be in Brussels - perhaps preparing for tomorrow's Eurogroup meeting of finance ministers. Yesterday, Stournaras denied that the Athens government and its troika inspectors were "miles" apart in their assessment of Greece's performance against its bailout programme. It's just meters, he insisted. Spain's annual inflation rate turned negative last month, according to new data that will heighten concerns that parts of the eurozone are slipping into deflation. The latest inflation data showed that the Spanish consumer prices index fell by 0.1% in October, on an annual basis. On a monthly basis, the CPI rose by 0.4%. On an 'EU harmonised basis', prices were flat year-on-year. We have seen a steady stream of low inflation rates recently (German's CPI fell to 1.2%), while the cost of living fell by 2.0% in Greece last month. Understandable, given sluggish demand, weak European growth and cash-strapped consumers. City traders are predicting the blue-chip Footsie index will drop by around 0.6%, when trading begins in a few minutes. Much was made of Mark Carney's Canadian background when he was named as Sir Mervyn King's successor. The FT has now discovered that he's also the proud holder of Irish citizenship too: Chris Giles reports: Since his arrival as governor of the Bank of England in July Mark Carney has had the luck of the Irish, enjoying rising growth, falling unemployment and rapidly moderating inflation. UK economics is centre-stage today, with the release of fresh unemployment data (at 9.30am) followed by the Bank of England's quarterly inflation report (from 10.30am). And what a difference three months makes. Back on August 7, governor Mark Carney pushed the Bank of England into a bold new era by setting 'forward guidance' on interest rates. Effectively he pledged that borrowing costs won't rise until the UK jobless rate drops to 7% (from 7.7% a month ago), which Carney didn't see happening until 2016. Since then, a rich seam of solid economic data has shown that Britain's economy is performing better than most analysts thought in August. So the Bank is likely to upgrade its growth forecasts, and could also predict that unemployment will fall faster than previously expected. And that could fuel predictions that UK interest rates will finally rise from their record low of 0.5% somewhat earlier than 2016. The unemployment data, meanwhile, is expected to show another drop in the number of people signing on for the Jobseeker's Allowance in October. The headline jobless rate is expected to stay at 7.7% for the three months to September. Michael Hewson of CMC helpfully rounds up the recent figures: The latest unemployment numbers look set to show the ILO September unemployment rate stuck at 7.7% despite double digit falls in jobless claims numbers for the last four months. Claims numbers for October are expected to show another double digit decline of 33k, following on from declines of 41.7k, 32.6k, 29.2k and 21.2k, in previous months. But with pay still lagging behind inflation (which fell to 2.2% yesterday), it may not feel like a recovery to many. We'll be tracking all the events through the day...

webTitle: FTSE falls nearly 1.5% on fears of rate rises and end of central bank stimulus

fields.standfirst: Leading shares record worst one day performance since middle of August on QE worries
fields.body:
As markets fell on concerns about an end to cheap money, supermarkets were in the spotlight, with J Sainsbury riding high after better than expected results but Tesco hit by an HSBC downgrade.

Sainsbury soared 11.9p to 410.7p making it the biggest riser in a falling FTSE 100, as it reported half year profits up 7% to £400m, compared to consensus forecasts of £394m.

Meanwhile Tesco fell 2.1p to 364.7p as HSBC said the supermarket was losing sales in the UK at the same time as costs were rising, while in Ireland it said the supermarket could be "heading to a meltdown". It cut its recommendation from overweight to neutral and moved its target price from 430p to 400p. Analyst Jerome Samuel said:

We are cutting forecasts to reflect ongoing concerns in Europe and Ireland, particularly. We cut our trading profit forecast for this year by 4.3% to £3,381m, and next year's by 5.7% to £3,617m.
Our previous positive stance had been based on Tesco delivering a promised 5.2% UK operating margin and while we still think Tesco will deliver this in 2013/14, we now think that holding on to this target when like for like sales are falling, may be the wrong strategy. We do not think 5.2% is a long term sustainable UK operating margin in a declining volume environment. Tesco is still losing like for like sales in the UK, after excluding maturing stores, online, refits, and extensions. Meanwhile like for like costs are rising, due to inflation and to Tesco investing into staff, refits, and infrastructure. All of this implies that a flat operating margin of 5.2% needs a rising gross margin to offset costs and the impact of adverse operational gearing from falling sales. In a market with declining demand, rising capacity and intense discounter competition, we question the wisdom of dogmatically holding on to this target. International is driving our downgrades and Ireland could be heading to a meltdown. The interim results highlighted how poor international has been performing with an on-going deterioration in trading. The interims showed every country in every region delivering like for like losses, with European trading profit down 70.8% at constant foreign exchange rates. Our updated forecasts reflect this poor performance and take account of our concerns for the second half. Ireland could be the next big disappointment. Recent market share data in Ireland saw Tesco losing 200 basis points of market share last quarter (source: Kantar) implying like for like sales were down around 6.5%. This is the 12th successive quarter of sales decline for Tesco. Ireland may be just 3.6% of sales but in profits, it is proportionately bigger and a profit collapse here, will move the dial on overall earnings per share. Unless management provides reassurance that the earnings downgrades are over, we do not expect the shares to rerate further despite a low valuation.

Overall, markets were unsettled by growing talk of an end to quantitative easing and the start of rising interest rates. Strong UK unemployment data and comments from the Bank of England suggested rates could rise sooner than expected, while US Federal Reserve members have been hinting it may begin to ease its $85bn a month bond buying programme later this year. Conversely, an ECB board member indicated the European bank might sanction negative deposit rates or bond buying to meet its inflation target.

Disappointment over the lack of detail in China's latest ten year economic plan did not help the market's mood, while there was also caution ahead of Thursday's testimony by Janet Yellen, who is President Obama's choice to take over from Ben Bernanke as head of the US Federal Reserve.

So the FTSE 100 finished 96.79 points at 6630.00, its biggest one day fall since 15 August.

RSA Insurance, under pressure after two profit warnings last week, lost another 5.3p to 104.1p as UBS cut its price target from 120p to 115p.

Standard Chartered dropped 37.5p to £14.48 on talk that its key emerging markets would be adversely affected when the central banks finally do turn off the money taps.

SSE slipped 6p lower to £13.99 as interim profits fell 12% despite rising consumer energy bills.

But power station owner Drax climbed 16.5p to 653p after it said it would materially beat market forecasts for full year profits, which currently stand at £203m. It has seen strong demand for its coal-fired generation and has also reported an encouraging performance from its first biomass unit.

Still with energy companies, BG dropped 21.5p to £12.48 after it said chief operating officer Martin Houston would step down from the board with immediate effect and retire from the group by the end of the year. Sami Iskander, executive vice president operations, will replace Houston, who has been with the company for 30 years.

A number of companies went ex-dividend, including BSkyB, down 35p to 805p. The satellite broadcaster has been hit recently by the news that rival BT had won the rights to the Champions League.

Among the mid-caps, Partnership Assurance lost a fifth of its value, down 87.1p to 325p, after a disappointing update.

The insurer, whose private equity backers floated the business in June at 385p a share, specialises in retirement annuities, said new business rose by 3% in the third quarter. But this was a marked slowdown on the 12% rise recorded in the first three months of the year and the 11% increase in the second quarter. It said it was on track to meet full year expectations for its operating profits, but added that the sales environment was "challenging."

Rival Just Retirement, which provides pensions to people with health problems and joined the market on Tuesday at 225p a share, fell 15.75p to 197.25p after the news from Partnership.

Elsewhere 3i shares sank 12.2p to 370.8p after an activist investor revealed it no longer had an interest in the private equity group.

Edward Bramson's Sherborne Investors, which had built up a 5% stake in 3i earlier in the year, said it had sold part of the stake and hedged the rest with derivatives, giving a net neutral position. It bought the shares at an average of 266p and sold them at 367p, giving a 38% return. It said:

[Sherborne] has indicated it believes that the risk of and rewards from new investments that it has identified offer better returns...than a continuing investment in 3i.

Mick Gilligan, head of research at Killik & Co, said:

We moved to a neutral position in 3i Group shares in late January, indicating that although the shares looked up with events that the attention of Sherborne Investors suggested there may be more unrecognised value in the portfolio This...news removes this source of support for the shares and, given the premium rating and lack of margin for error, in our view, we are moving to a sell recommendation on 3i Group shares and removing the group from coverage.

webTitle: Hornby sees 'light at the end of the tunnel' after sales fall

fields.standfirst: Model railway maker reports a £700,000 loss for the six months to the end of September
fields.body:
Model railway maker Hornby has reported falling sales but insisted there was "light at the end of the tunnel" as it approached the crucial Christmas selling season, having made progress on resolving supply chain difficulties.

The toy company, which also makes Scalextric cars and Humbrol paints, revealed a £700,000 loss for the six months to the end of September, compared with £200,000 for the same period in the previous year. Turnover dipped by 4% to £22m, stripping out the effects of a disastrous Olympics that left the company sitting on mountains of unsold London 2012-themed goods.

The firm, which traces its origins back to 1901 when Frank Hornby received his first patent for Meccano, has had a rough few years, with hobby retailer partner Modelzone going bust this summer, while changing consumer trends suggest children are turning to iPads and games consoles over model-making and train sets.

Roger Canham, Hornby's chairman, insisted demand remained strong. "Our only challenge is to get the products to market," he said. "Most parents don't want their children sat in front of the TV gaming all the time."

The toy company faced disruption when one of its Shenzhen-based suppliers, facing worker shortages and rising costs, moved one of its factories, hitting model railway supplies. In a bid to prevent future supply problems, Hornby has signed contracts with six additional Chinese plants and returned some manufacturing to the UK. A plant in Newhaven, Sussex, is working 24 hours a day to build the company's Airfix Quickbuild range of model planes that do not require glue. "During the last six months we have been focusing very heavily on our supply chain difficulties and we are starting to see the light at the end of the tunnel," Canham said.

He added that trading had been positive in recent months. The company said it would have 35 concessions in branches of WHSmith and gift chain Hawkins Bazaar by the end of the year to fill the gap left by Modelzone.

A plant in Newhaven, Sussex, is working 24 hours a day to build the company's Airfix Quickbuild range of model planes that do not require glue. "During the last six months we have been focusing very heavily on our supply chain difficulties and we are starting to see the light at the end of the tunnel," Canham said. He added that trading had been positive in recent months. The company said it would have 35 concessions in branches of WHSmith and gift chain Hawkins Bazaar by the end of the year to fill the gap left by Modelzone.
